p: In contrast to that, AAF/I, AAF/III, and AAF/V showed aggregates that were partially reminiscent of the strictly two-dimensional “stacked-brick” pattern described for the corresponding wild type cells [ 24] ( Figure 7, note loci with less dense bacterial aggregates). However, most of the formed bacterial aggregates were rather three-dimensional, which may have disturbed the formation of a regular two-dimensional arrangement. Notably, the bacteria expressing AAF/I formed the largest aggregates on HEp-2 cells ( Figure 7), as previously observed for the corresponding EHEC O104:H4 outbreak strain [ 24]. Thus, this appears to be a trait that is mediated directly by this specific AAF subtype.
